UK PM Johnson is planning to tell the Queen she cannot sack him even if he loses a no confidence vote and MPs pick a caretaker replacement
content:
Senior No10 aides are preparing legal advice for the monarch to ensure Boris can stay on to try to deliver Brexit on Oct 31st

The Queen can decline a nationwide vote if three conditions are met:

  • Parliament is still “vital, viable, and capable of doing its job”
  • An election would be “detrimental to the national economy"
  • And, if an alternative PM emerges and can govern “for a reasonable period with a working majority in the House of Commons”.

 

But No10 advisers now think the principles can be flipped and used as founding reasons why the Queen must also keep a serving PM in place.

9th October 2019 

TRADE

US imposed Visa bans against Chinese individuals related to abuse of China's Uighur community. (Newswires)

China is toning down expectations head of US/China trade talks, the round of talks will take place this week, but a source says that the Chinese delegation is already planning to cut short its stay in Washington by one night. (SCMP)

Vice Premier Liu He will lead one of the largest delegations, which signalled China is sincerely looking to reach a comprehensive trade deal with the US, although it is not sure whether the US will hike imports on Chinese tariffs; China Global Times. (Global Times)

China wishes to reach an agreement, but China has not made an urgent timetable for itself, Global Times reported. The article added that neither Chinese nor US society has high expectations for the two countries to reach an agreement soon, since the two countries still have trade conflicts and their strategic mistrust continues to rise. To reach an agreement, the Chinese and the US governments need to show political determination and make major efforts. Meanwhile, China Global Times Editor Huxijin said he can feel that the Chinese society has low expectations for a real breakthrough in the new round of trade talks. (Global Times/Twitter)

The White House is reportedly said to be focusing on limiting China stocks and government funds. The Trump administration is moving ahead with discussions around possible restrictions on capital flows into China, with a particular focus on investments made by US government pension funds, say people familiar with the internal deliberations. (Newswires)

China's MOFCOM urges the US to remove the latest sanctions, to stop making "irresponsible" remarks on the Xinjiang issue and to stop interfering in China's internal affairs; will take measures to protect its interests. White House Trade Adviser Navarro said the blacklisting of Chinese companies is unrelated to the trade talks, reiterates they want a big deal with China. (Newswires)

 

US

Fed Chair Powell said Fed will soon announce measure to add to reserves supply over time, time is now upon us to expand balance sheet to maintain appropriate level of reserves, should not be confused with QE. Purchases of treasury bills to resolve the recent technical issues will not materially affect monetary policy stance. Powell also noted that jobs and inflation picture is favourable, sees continued economic expansion, a strong labour market and inflation near 2% goal as most likely outlook, reiterates global development pose risks to a favourable outlook in the US. The Fed Chair said the economy feels sustainable, no aspect is booming, and economy is not hot. Powell reaffirmed recent comments from Fed members, stating that the Fed will assess outlook on a meeting by meeting basis, policy is never on a pre-set course and it will change as appropriate. (Newswires)

Fed's Evans (Voter, Dove) said he would not mind another interest rate cut. He believes downside risks to the economy are stronger than the upside risks; consumer is benefiting from a strong labour market; he is looking for 2% growth in 2020 and is still optimistic on the US outlook, economy is good. Evans added that the repo-market pressures have now subsided and that the extension of operations to November 4th are helpful. (Newswires) Reminder, the latest Fed dot plots saw 7/17 members see 1 more rate cut this year.

Fed’s Rosengren (voter, hawkish dissenter) said the data has come out a little weaker than he had anticipated a few weeks ago; still a tight labour market and nothing to indicate the consumer fundamentals have changed, according to WSJ. (WSJ)

US House Intelligence Panel Chair Schiff says the State Department is withholding text from US Ambassadors to the EU on a personal device relevant to the impeachment inquiry. (Newswires)

IBD/TIPP economic optimism rebounds in October despite political turmoil. (IBD/TIPP)

DATA RECAP

- US PPI Final Demand MM (Sep) -0.3% vs. Exp. 0.1% (Prev. 0.1%) (Newswires) - US PPI Final Demand YY (Sep) 1.4% vs. Exp. 1.8% (Prev. 1.8%)

 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson was told by German Chancellor Merkel this morning that there could only be a deal if Northern Ireland stays in the custom union, if not, a deal is overwhelmingly unlikely, according to BBC's Kuenssberg. (Twitter) UK PM Johnson has had a "constructive" call with Irish PM Varadkar, pair to meet in Dublin, Ireland on Thursday or Friday, according to sources cited by The Sun. (The Sun)

EU Parliament President Sassoli said UK PM Johnson would not request a Brexit extension from the EU and if there is a will and a proposal from the UK, there is a possibility of a deal. (Newswires)

EU hearing rumours PM may not come to leaders’ summit next week if no deal in sight. Further, EU diplomats say they will not meet in middle over UK PM Johnson's Brexit proposals reports BBC's Adler. (Twitter)

ECB's de Cos says the evidence suggests that we are yet to reach a reversal rate. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS 

US President Trump was more positive on Turkey; acknowledged the country is an important trade partner (notes production of parts for F-35), praises them for returning Pastor Brunson last year, notes Erdogan coming to US on 13 November. US President Trump said we have not abandoned the Kurds, any unforced/unnecessary fighting by Turkey will be devastating to their economy and their fragile currency; are assisting the Turks financially/weapons. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

FX

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 8th October 2019: US-China tensions intensify; Powell to expand balance sheet
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

US MARKET WRAP 8th October 2019: US-China tensions intensify; Powell to expand balance sheet

 

* SNAPSHOT: Equities down, Treasuries up, Dollar up, Crude down.

* REAR VIEW: Powell sticks to script, Fed will soon announce measures to add to reserves, US puts visa bans on individuals related to the detaining of Uighurs, China delegation said to leave one day early, soft US PPI.

* UPCOMING: Data: US JOLTS, EIA Weekly Crude Inventories and Crude Production. Events: FOMC Minutes. Speakers: Fed’s Powell. Auctions: US 10-year.

 

* MARKET WRAP: Markets continued their sell off on Tuesday as tensions between US & China intensified - the US sanctioned entities in relation to the detained Uighurs last night and earlier source reports stated the China delegation is to leave a day early, adding to the risk off feel. Selling continued in the tail end of the session as the US announced it is to impose visa bans against unnamed individuals related to the Uighur community. The yield curve saw bull steepening as Fed Chair Powell said “time is now upon us to expand the balance sheet to maintain appropriate level of reserves”, in addition to Fed’s Evans voicing the need for a further rate cut, although other risk assets were little changed as trade themes dominated the narrative. Elsewhere, Brexit uncertainties continue to weaken the pound; EIA cut its oil demand outlook again; Kurds look to US foes for support against a Turkey military operation. 

* FED CHAIR POWELL: Fed Chair Powell announced the Fed will soon announce measures to add reserve supply over time, adding time is now upon us to expand the balance sheet to maintain an appropriate level of reserves. Powell noted the purchases of T-bills will not materially effect the Fed’s monetary policy stance as it is to address recent technical issues, Powell also added it is not to be confused with QE. On the economy, he said that the jobs and inflation picture is favourable, he sees a continued economic expansion and there was no reason why it could not continue; he also sees a strong labour market and inflation near the 2% goal as the most likely outlook. He judged that vulnerability in the financial system are moderate overall, and that households were in good shape. Powell reiterated global developments pose risks to a positive outlook in the US. The Fed chair also noted that the policy actions were providing support to the outlook, reiterating policy is never on a pre-set course, and it will change as appropriate, taking meetings one-by-one. Powell maintained the Fed’s language on the outlook that it will act ‘as appropriate’ to support growth, a strong job market and for inflation to return to its 2% goal.

* CHINA TRADE: The US added a further eight Chinese tech companies to its trade blacklist, with the Commerce Department saying that the "entities have been implicated in human rights violations and abuses in the implementation of China’s campaign of repression, mass arbitrary detention, and high-technology surveillance against Uighurs, Kazakhs, and other members of Muslim minority groups." Ahead of high-level trade talks this week (which will be attended by China's Vice Premier Liu He and PBoC Governor Yi and Treasury Secretary Mnuchin as well as USTR Lighthizer) US officials said the action was not linked to these negotiations. A China MOFCOM official said "stay tuned" for Beijing's retaliation. In the tail-end of the session, the US imposed Visa bans on Chinese linked to the mass detention of Uighur Muslims in the Xinjiang province. Before the US open, it was reported that Chinese officials were toning down expectations, with a source stating the delegation is already planning to cut short its stay by one night, SCMP reported. Additionally, Trump reportedly also expressed hope that China find a resolution to the ongoing protests in Hong Kong, warning that the situation had the potential to hurt trade talks; the remark will likely anger China, which has demanded other nations remain out of its domestic affairs. There is some speculation that the two developments may be a response to a weekend story that China was seeking to 'narrow' the scope of trade talks as it saw US President Trump's domestic woes as strengthening its hand in negotiations; the US has been insisting that small, piecemeal trade deals may not cut it. Nevertheless, the stories here highlights the difficulties the two teams will face in trying to strike a trade deal, and as such, expectations remain low, as evidenced by commentary in China's People's Daily, which stated talks could deliver a fair deal, fall apart or even maintain the current state of 'talking while retaliating.' Additionally, it is worth keeping in mind that, in one week, the US is set to boost tariffs on USD 25bln of Chinese imports (originally slated for 1st October but delayed at Beijing's request) from 25% to 30%.

* FED MINUTES PREVIEW: FOMC September Meeting Minutes will be released on 9th October 2019 at 1900 BST/1400 EDT. Focus will be on clues into conditions for further rate cuts as well as any talk around a permanent standing repo facility. The minutes come ahead of key trade talks between the US and China which are likely to set sentiment. To download the report, please click here.

* FED: Fed's Rosengren (voter, hawkish dissenter) said incoming data had come in a little weaker than he had anticipated a few weeks ago. Rosengren said the Fed sees the labour market still tight, and there was nothing to indicate that consumer fundamentals have changed. Elsewhere, he warned on some asset prices, stating that he was concerned about co-working environments on the commercial real estate market. Fed’s Evans (Voter, Dove) said he would not mind another rate cut, downside risks to the economy were stronger than the upside risks; he believes the consumer is benefiting from a strong labour market. Looking ahead, Evans sees 2% growth in 2020, and said he was still optimistic on the US outlook, adding the economy is good' he did, however, opine that last week's manufacturing report was not a good sign.

* BREXIT: Reports indicate that German Chancellor Merkel told PM Johnson this morning that there can only be a Brexit deal if Northern Ireland remains in the customs union. A UK source noted that the discussion was a ‘clarifying moment’ in discussions and if this represents a new established position from Europe that a deal is essentially impossible at any point, not just now. These comments did lead to some significant broad-based Sterling depreciation, which boosted the FTSE 100 briefly, and caused Gilts to firm up. However, it’s worth clarifying that there has been some speculation as to whether these comments were from Chancellor Merkel herself, as they are notably different from the peace-maker stance she tends to take in EU-UK conflict. Subsequently, a German spokesman did confirm the call occurred though they will not elaborate on the details. The remainder of the sessions Brexit news flow has largely just been noise as we approach the Friday deadline for Johnson to potentially submit any revisions and, of course, next week’s EU summit. Later in the session, European Parliament President Sassoli said that UK PM Johnson had told him that he would not request a Brexit extension from the EU.

* IBD/TIPP ECONOMIC OPTIMISM: The IBD/TIPP Economic Optimism Index rose 3.5% to 52.6 in October, reversing two months of decline. The index now remains above 50.0 for a record 37 consecutive months. The Six-Month Economic Outlook increased by 1.2%. However, the component remains in negative territory with a reading of 43.5, up from 43.0 last month, which was the lowest reading in three years. The Personal Financial Outlook rose by 2.4% in October, after dropping by 5.4% in September; it yielded a reading of 60.6 this month, compared to 59.2 last month. Confidence in Federal Economic Policies, a proprietary IBD/TIPP measure of views on how government economic policies are working, reversed a two-month slide in October, moving from 50.3 last month to 53.6-- a 6.6% increase. "Consumer sentiment continues to be strong despite the trade war with China and the stock market under pressure," the report stated, "the job market continues to be good, with the unemployment rate falling to a 50-year low." The report also noted that nearly half of respondents think that the economy is improving, and a similar share gives high marks to the President for his handling of the economy -- a factor behind the increase in Trump’s Job Approval rating from 39% in September to 43% this month, despite the impeachment talk.

* US PPI: Printed -0.3% M/M in September, a downside surprise from the expected +0.1% (also the previous), bringing the Y/Y down to +1.4% from the prior +1.8%. The core M/M also disappointed – printing -0.3% against the expected +0.2%. Pantheon Macroeconomics note that the 1% plunge in the trade services component (a measure of wholesale and retail profit margins) half explains the weakness in the core, whilst the data also shows falls in both margins of capital and consumer goods. Looking historically the consultancy says on a Y/Y basis capital goods margins are little changed, likely a result of China tariffs, whilst consumer goods margins have gained 3.5%. PM caveats by noting the volatile nature of the data and a rebound in October is a “decent bet” and overall PPI inflation remains under control.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z9) SETTLED 6 TICKS HIGHER AT 131.22+: The TPLEX was pretty much unchanged going into remarks by Fed Chair Powell, and then steepened in wake of his comments, where he said that the Fed soon announce measures to add to reserves supply over time, and that the time was now upon us to expand balance sheet in order to maintain an appropriate level of reserves, warning that such moves should not be framed as ‘QE’. In wake of Powell’s comments, the implied probability of a 25bps rate cut rose to around 80% from around 75% at the close of business on Monday.  The US Treasury kicked-off the week’s Treasury supply with a lacklustre sale of 3s, which tailed by 0.4bps, while cover came in below recent averages; the paper was sold at the lowest 3s auction yield since November 2016. There was little impact on the curve after the auction.

* US 10-YEAR NOTE PREVIEW: The Treasury will this week auction a new 3-year note (USD 38bln, Tue), a 10-year re-opening (USD 24bln, Wed), and a 30-year bond re-opening (USD 16bln, Thu). Excluding SOMA holdings, there will be around USD 26bln of cash flows this week (around USD 24bln of redemptions, and USD 2bln of coupons). Societe Generale's analysts say the 10-year sector has been set-up for auction from a relative value perspective, and argues that the current 10 trades fair in asset swap compared to previous 10-year auction cycles, though is cheap on the curve versus 5s and 30s. SocGen thinks that on an outright basis the 10-year part of the curve appears rich, with the current WI trading beneath all stop-out rates since August 2016. The bank also notes that the bull-steepening of the 2s10s part of the curve since the last auction cycles signals that, although the sector has cheapened on a relative value basis, it is expensive outright. Additionally, dealer holdings in the 7-11-year bucket is high, suggesting that the success of the auction will hinge on the participation of investment funds and foreigners. Finally, the bank says it holds a negative bias into this auction, though says that the fact that 10s trades special in repo might support demand.

* EIA STEO: Cut 2019 2019 world oil demand growth forecasts by 50k BPD to an 840k BPD Y/Y increase, and cut its 2020 forecast by 100k BPD and to a 1.3mln BPD Y/Y increase. Whilst US crude output is to rise 1.27mln BPD to 12.26mln BPD in 2019 (prev. +1.25mln BPD), to rise 910k BPD to 13.17mln BPD in 2020 (prev. a smaller rise to 13.23mln BPD). Forecasts Brent averaging USD 59/bbl in Q4 19, falling to USD 57/bbl Q2 20, before rising to more than USD 62/bbl in H2 20 as oil market balances firm; sees Brent averaging USD 60/bbl in 2020 (prev. USD 62/bbl), notably due to contractionary manufacturing indicators from the US and Germany and higher inventory builds in 2020.

* WTI (X9) SETTLED USD 0.12 LOWER AT USD 52.63/BBL; BRENT (Z9) SETTLED USD 0.11 LOWER AT USD 58.24/BBL: Mounting pessimistic sentiment ahead of the US-China trade talks this week saw oil benchmarks follow risk lower. Growing consensus that the scope of a trade outcome is to be limited this week is sequentially weighing on the crude complex as participants revaluate global demand. The wildcard in the energy markets that is Iranian conflict remains just as much a downside risk as much as an upside one, where any form of agreement between Tehran and Washington is likely to knock out some of the geopolitical risk premium currently supporting the crude complex from taking further losses. The API reports its US energy inventories ahead of the official EIA release on Wednesday – current expectations see crude stocks +1.4mln bbls, distillates -2.1mln bbls and gasoline -0.3mln bbls, whilst Genscape sees Cushing stocks +0.348mln bbls.

* SYRIA/TURKEY: Kurdish officials are now reportedly reaching out for help to Syria’s Assad and the Russians, following US President Trump’s decision to withdraw from the region, putting Kurdish forces at risk of further attacks from Turkey (who has said all preparations are completed for a military operation). Trump has received strong backlash to the moves both abroad and domestically – on both sides of the isle – where concerns lie in the benefit the situation provides to Russia, Iran and the Assad regime.

* CLOSING LEVELS: S&P 500 -1.6% at 2893, NASDAQ-100 -1.6% at 7604, Dow Jones -1.2% at 26164,

Tesla competitor NIO (NIO) delivered 4799 vehicles in Q3, a 35.1% Q/Q increase. Dominos (DPZ) earnings missed both top and bottom line however initial losses were clawed back, even amid a market rout, to eventually close positive following positive comments from its earnings call, as it sticks to its aggressive growth plans, as the CEO noted they have a unique opportunity to solidify market share gains for the long term. On the food delivery service, CEO stated they believe that a significant shakeout is coming, as the delivery charges competitors such as GrubHub (GRUB) much lower prices than what it costs, thanks to subsidies from investors.

* FX WRAP: USD: DXY is higher heading into the Asia session, having started out on the backfoot seeing lows beneath 98.90, however the index reclaimed the 99.0 handle as risk appetite soured, with direction little changed as Powell generally stuck to the script.

Havens: JPY, CHF and XAU all bid today as US/China trade tensions came to the fore ahead of high-level trade talks; USDJPY remaining above the 107-handle heading into Asia trade. XAU reclaimed the 1500 handle, while CHF also bid.

GBP: Brexit headline risk weighs on GBP, pushing it sub-1.22 at one point, uncertainties continue as the deadline fast approaches. Initial reports suggested that German Chancellor Merkel said that unless Northern Ireland stays in the customs union, a deal is overwhelmingly unlikely and essentially impossible. However, these comments were never confirmed, and the German government refused to comment on them, nonetheless GBP remained on the back food today with Cable trading between 1.22 and 1.23 parameters, with the cross heavily supported at 1.22 with bids cited between 1.2295-1.22; EURGBP found resistance within a whisker of 0.90.

Antipodes: AUD and NZD headed into Asia trade relatively flat despite trading higher throughout the European session, NZD was boosted by data showing a surprise NZD 4bln budget surplus, above expectations. However, the overhanging US China trade tensions saw both AUD and NZD gains pare back.

EMFX: BRL outperformed as Brazil’s economy minister Guedes denied reports from yesterday that he is to step down from his role in February; also, of note, Brazil senate will hold the second vote on the pension reform on Oct. 22nd. TRY headed into the Asia session flat, although US President Trump did seem to step back from his aggressive approach yesterday, as he called them a big trading partner, good to deal with and have helped Trump save lives; Trump and Erdogan are to meet on November 13th in the US.

subject: PREVIEW: US to sell USD 38bln of 3-year notes on 8th October 2019 at 1300 EDT/1800 BST
content:
THIS WEEK'S SUPPLY: The Treasury will this week auction a new 3-year note (USD 38bln, Tue), a 10-year re-opening (USD 24bln, Wed), and a 30-year bond re-opening (USD 16bln, Thu). Excluding SOMA holdings, there will be around USD 26bln of cash flows this week (around USD 24bln of redemptions, and USD 2bln of coupons).

3-YEAR PREVIEW: The complex lacks setup ahead of the auction from a relative value perspective, Societe Generale says, and trades rich in asset swap, and on the curve versus 2s and 5s. The bank thinks the sector appears expensive on an outright basis, with the current when-issued trading below all auction stop out rates since November 2016. The richening of 3s on the curve appears to be a result of the bull-steepening seen since the last auction. SocGen notes that after the recent, Treasuries appear to be consolidating and may be range-bound into the sale, though disruption is possible from geopolitics, of course. Low dealer holdings in the 3s bucket could be supportive of the auction, SocGen argues, though six of the last ten auctions have tailed, adding to the negatives.

RECENT 3-YEAR NOTE AUCTION HISTORY:

Daily FX Wrap: Pound perilously close to 1.2200 and 0.9000 as no deal Brexit beckons
content:
GBP

Sterling losses have steadily accumulated, initially on reports of a rather full and frank exchange of views between UK PM Johnson and German Chancellor Merkel that was said to be challenging and described as a clarifying moment by Number 10 sources, with the upshot that a deal may never be unreachable. Subsequently, EU’s Tusk accused Johnson of engaging in blame games rather than trying to forge an agreement, but the EC maintained that further talks planned for today will go ahead. Nevertheless, although the writing may not yet be on the wall, reading between the lines indicates that the chances of a compromise on the Irish border and customs arrangement are getting slimmer, and Cable has extended losses through last week’s low (1.2205) to the figure or just below, while Eur/Gbp got to within a whisker of 0.9000 before fading as the single currency continued to hit resistance into 1.1000 against the Dollar.

CHF/JPY/NZD

No shock to see the Franc and Yen outperform on risk-off grounds, partly due to the Brexit developments noted above, but also as the SCMP suggested that China has toned down expectations gong into this week’s Washington trade talks, and may head back to Beijing a day earlier than scheduled. Moreover, head of the Chinese delegation, Lui He will apparently not be adorned with the title of special envoy, which indicates no particular instructions from China’s Premier and perhaps a limited remit for any form of accord. Usd/Chf is hovering just above 0.9900 and Usd/Jpy has pulled back further from around 107.45 through 107.00, but perhaps more surprisingly the Kiwi is also bid, albeit on positive NZ specifics and favourable cross winds. To recap, Nzd/Usd was boosted by the Finance Ministry announcing a 4 bn budget surplus over and above forecast, on top of AUD/Nzd slipping deeper below 1.0700 amidst a drift in Aud/Usd from 0.6750+ towards 0.6730 as the Aussie lost momentum on the aforementioned US-China trade news.

CNH/CAD/EUR   

All on a weaker footing vs the Greenback amidst broad risk aversion, as the DXY straddles 99.000 in a firmer, though still tight range (99.137-98.842) despite considerably weaker than consensus US PPI data. The off-shore Yuan down through 7.1500, Loonie back below 1.3300, but off wort levels following upbeat Canadian housing starts and building permits and Euro nearer the base of 1.0995-53 parameters after topping out ahead of hefty option expiries spanning 1.1000 (1.3 bn from 1.0995-1.1005 to be precise) and not far from the 21 DMA yet again (1.0993).

EM

Volatile trade across the board and especially for the Lira as US President Trump seemed much more friendly to Turkey when noting its close trade relationship and decision to release Pastor Brunson in 2018, in contrast to his blast and warning to obliterate the economy if its military ops in Syria went out of bounds. Usd/Try has traded up to 5.8450+ and sub-5.7850 at the other extreme, while the Real has pared losses within 4.1125-0800 boundaries after Brazilian Economy Minister Guedes scotched speculation that he plans to depart from the Government in February 2020.

IBD/TIPP economic optimism rebounds in October despite political turmoil
content:
• The IBD/TIPP Economic Optimism Index rose 3.5% to 52.6 in October, reversing two months of decline. 
  • The index now remains above 50.0 for a record 37 consecutive months.
  • The Six-Month Economic Outlook, a measure of how consumers feel about the economy’s prospects in the next six months, increased by 1.2%. However, the component remains in negative territory with a reading of 43.5, up from 43.0 last month, which was the lowest reading in three years. Nevertheless,     
  • The Personal Financial Outlook, a measure of how Americans feel about their own finances in the next six months, rose by 2.4% in October after dropping by 5.4% in September. It yielded a reading of 60.6 this month, compared to 59.2 last month.
  • Confidence in Federal Economic Policies, a proprietary IBD/TIPP measure of views on how government economic policies are working, reversed a two-month slide in October, moving from 50.3 last month to 53.6-- a 6.6% increase.
  • "Consumer sentiment continues to be strong despite the trade war with China and the stock market under pressure. The job market continues to be good, with the unemployment rate falling to a 50-year low. Nearly one half of respondents think that the economy is improving, and a similar share gives high marks to the President for his handling of the economy -- a factor behind the increase in Trump’s Job Approval rating from 39% in September to 43% this month, despite the impeachment talk,” said  Raghavan Mayur, president of TechnoMetrica who directed the poll. 
  • Via IBD/TIPP

subject: Nissan (7201 JP, NSANY) is to appoint executive Makoto Uchida as its next CEO
RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 8th October 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • China is toning down exp. ahead of trade talks, delegation are planning to cut the visit short and Liu He has not been given the designation of Special Envoy., SCMP
  • China’s Commerce Ministry say to stay tuned for retaliation to the US naming 28 Co’s to be placed on their entity list
  • German Chancellor Merkel reportedly told PM Johnson that a deal can only occur if NI remains in the customs union, if this is the EU’s position than a UK source notes that a deal is essentially impossible at any point
  • Risk-off trade continues to extend on trade updates with UK assets also afflicted on Brexit; as such, GBP is the notable G10 underperformer
  • Looking ahead highlights include US PPI and EIA STEO, Fed’s Powell, Evans and Kashkari, supply from the US

TRADE

US President Trump said if anything bad happened in HK, it would be bad for US/China trade talks, whilst he reiterated the US is shooting for a big deal with China and there is a good possibility of a deal. Further, the Chinese trade delegation, including Vice Premier Liu He will be in Washington on October 10/11th for trade talks. (Newswires)

US Commerce Department confirmed it is naming 28 Chinese governmental and commercial organisations - including Hikvision - to the entity list over treatment of the Muslim Uighur community, effective Monday. (Newswires)

China's Ministry of Commerce says to stay tuned for a blacklist retaliation, following the US blacklisting a number of Chinese Co’s, particularly surveillance related ones. (Newswires)

China is toning down expectations head of US/China trade talks, the round of talks will take place this week, but a source says that the Chinese delegation is already planning to cut short its stay in Washington by one night, reports SCMP; Chinese negotiator Liu He will not carry the title of “special envoy” for President Xi Jinping, which the article says is an early indication that the vice-premier has not been given any particular instructions from China’s leader. (SCMP)

ASIA-PAC

Asian equities traded higher across the board despite a lacklustre handover from Wall Street where stocks were choppy but ultimately closed in the red amid trade war jitters after the US blacklisted Chinese governmental and commercial organisations over treatment of the Muslim minority community. ASX 200 (+0.4%) was kept afloat by miners amid favourable price action in base metals, whilst Nikkei 225 (+1.0%) was bolstered on the back of a weaker Yen and after US and Japan signed a limited trade deal on agricultural and digital trade. Hang Seng (+0.2%) and Shanghai Comp (+0.3%) returned from a long weekend and played catchup to the NFP-induced upside in the prior session. The former was buoyed by heavyweights Geely Auto after dealers noted a pickup in sales during Golden Week, whilst HKEX shares rose in excess of 2% after it dropped its GBP 32bln bid for LSE, as the boards of the two companies were “unable to engage”. Meanwhile, Mainland China saw upside despite the Caixin Services metric falling short of forecasts, as an improvement in the Composite metric signalled the strongest rate of growth since April. Furthermore, South Korea’s KOSPI (+0.8%) showed a strong performance as the index was supported by tech giant Samsung Electronics, who’s shares spiked higher by 1% after its Q3 guidance topped analyst expectations, albeit it still noted that its profits will likely plunge 56% Y/Y. Finally, core fixed-income futures drifted lower and tracked the risk sentiment around the market with UST and Bund futures poised to close Asia trade near session lows.

Hong Kong Chief Executive Lam said she has no plans to introduce other laws using the emergency regulation ordnance, it's too early to say the anti-mask law is ineffective. (Newswires) Reports, citing the Chief Executive, noted that the Chinese military could step in if the ongoing protests in the city get worse. (Sputnik) The Hong Kong leader also noted that during Golden week, the number of visitors declined 50% Y/Y. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0726 vs. Exp. 7.0799 (Prev. 7.0729) (Newswires) PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 250bln

Chinese Caixin Services PMI (Sep) 51.3 vs. Exp. 52.1 (Prev. 52.1) - Seven month low (Newswires) Chinese Caixin Composite PMI (Sep) 51.9 (Prev. 51.6) - signals the strongest rate of growth since April (Markit)

GEOPOLITICS

Turkish Defence Ministry says all preparations are complete for the military operation into Syria, whilst reports stated that US does not endorse any Turkish operations in northern Syria, according to a senior administration official cited by VOA News’ Steve Herman, who added that US troops will be withdrawn from the Turkey-Syria border, not out of Syria entirely. (Twitter)

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson was told by German Chancellor Merkel this morning that there could only be a deal if Northern Ireland stays in the custom union, if not, a deal is overwhelmingly unlikely, according to BBC's Kuenssberg. (Twitter) EU’s position is that a deal is ‘essentially impossible, not just now – but ever’. And talks in Brussels are close to breaking down; although, this afternoons talks are expected to occur. (Twitter)

Unless the EU compromises and does a Brexit deal shortly, then the UK will leave the EU without a deal, according to a senior Downing Street source. (Newswires)

UK Downing Street contact believes that negotiations will probably end this week, and added Irish PM Varadkar does not want to talk anymore, and German Chancellor Merkel and French President Macron will not push EU’s Chief Brexit Negotiator Barnier unless Ireland says it wants to negotiate, according to The Spectator’s James Forsyth. Furthermore, UK and EU negotiators will be meeting this morning, according to Buzzfeed's Nardelli, who added that EU diplomats were also told that there haven't been significant developments on the declaration outlining the future relationship. (Twitter) UK Downing Street said the EU governments which oppose a Brexit delay will be rewarded by UK PM Johnson, and that if the EU approves a delay Johnson will do his best to sabotage the functioning of the EU, pending Brexit, ITV's Peston. (Twitter)

UK borrowing could rise to GBP 100bln in the case of a no-deal Brexit, accordion to think tank IFS. Furthermore, the body notes that the nation cannot afford the tax cuts that PM Johnson has pledged during the Conservative leadership campaign. (BBC/Times)

US Secretary of State Pompeo tweeted that he had a great discussion with UK Foreign Secretary Raab, "We discussed our intentions to negotiate an ambitious future free trade agreement, ways to counter Iran’s influence in the Middle East, and Turkey"

 

EQUITIES

 

Major European Bourses (Euro Stoxx 50 -0.9%) are lower, with the region shrugging off a positive AsiaPac hand over, as trade jitters return to the forefront following the flurry of headlines yesterday evening. This morning, China's Ministry of Commerce said to stay tuned for a blacklist retaliation to the recent US decision to list 28 Chinese governmental and commercial organisations, including Hikvision, to the entity list over treatment of the Muslim Uighur community. Further contributing to the downbeat tone, SCMP reported that China is toning down expectations head of US/China trade talks, and even though the round of talks will take place this week, a source says that the Chinese delegation is already planning to cut short its stay in Washington by one night. Moreover, Chinese negotiator Liu He will not carry the title of “special envoy” for President Xi Jinping at the meeting, which the article speculated is an early indication that the vice-premier has not been given any particular instructions from China’s leader. Separately, but also contributing some downside to global equities, was a return of no deal Brexit fears, with UK/EU talks seemingly approaching collapse and the UK government vowed to pursue a no deal exit unless the EU compromises. The confluence of negatives saw DAX Dec’ 19 futures lose the 12000 handle. Moving forward, further impetus likely to come in the form of Fed speak (including Powell at 19.30 BST) and Minutes tomorrow and US/China trade talks, US CPI and ECB Minutes on Thursday. Sectors are lower apart from Telecoms (unch.). In terms of individual movers; Airbus (+0.7%) shares were supported by a strong delivery update. Wirecard (-2.8%) initially moved higher after the Co. announced an increase to its Vision 2025 targets, before paring gains alongside the market. EasyJet (-6.3%) shares fell after a trading update; on the face of it the update appeared strong, however investors noted that they had been expecting firmer guidance, while also suggesting that the co.’s decision to not to have a conference call was a mistake. London Stock Exchange (-4.8%) sunk on news that the Hong Kong Exchange and Clearing will no longer proceed with their offer for the Co. Uniper (-8.2%) shares fell and Fortum (-0.2%) initially rose after the former announced it had agreed to acquire a majority stake in the latter, before falling with the market.

 

Boeing (BA) - Frictions between European and US regulators may result in a delay for the 737 Max returning to service; specifically, heightened European safety concerns regarding proposed flight-control fixes., WSJ citing sources. (WSJ)

 

FX

 

NZD/AUD/SEK/TRY - Not quite all change, but certainly some solace for the Kiwi, Aussie, Swedish Crown and Turkish Lira following a bad start to the week. Nzd/Usd has regained 0.6300+ status on the back of supportive fiscal impulses as the NZ Finance Minister flagged a 4 bn budget surplus overshoot against target overnight, while Aud/Usd is hovering above 0.6750 in wake of mixed Chinese Caixin PMIs and an uptick in NAB business conditions. Elsewhere, Eur/Sek has eased back from 10.8900+ peaks towards 10.8500 with the aid of some encouraging Swedish data (private/services production and Usd/Try retreated from around 5.8450 to sub-5.8000 at one stage after US President Trump threatened to decimate the Turkish economy if it crosses the line in Northern Syria.

GBP - In stark contrast to all the above, no deal Brexit risk has put the Pound back on the rack amidst reports that German Chancellor Merkel deems that a breakthrough on the Irish backstop is now highly unlikely, while other headlines contend that an agreement may be dead in the water full stop. In response, Cable lost grip of the 1.2300 handle and filled bids at 1.2275 before ploughing through more between 1.2260-50 on the way through 1.2230, while Eur/Gbp spiked to just over 0.8980 and beyond 500 mn option expiries at 0.8965.

CHF/EUR/JPY - All firmer against the Dollar even though the DXY nudged back over 99.000 ahead of US PPI and Fed Chair Powell, with an element of underlying safe-haven demand underpinning the Franc, Yen and Euro awaiting US-China trade talks alongside the aforementioned Brexit negotiations on the cusp of collapsing. Usd/Chf is closer to 0.9900, Eur/Usd near the top end of a 1.0965-95 band and Usd/Jpy eyeing 107.00 again from circa 107.45 earlier. Note, latest SCMP reports confirms earlier talk that Beijing is not looking for any major deal and propose to cut their stay short, with Liu He not attending in the guise of special envoy that would imply no remit or agenda to sign off on a full trade agreement.

NOK/CAD - The Norwegian Krona and Loonie are both holding relatively steady around 10.0400 vs the single currency and 1.3300 vs the Greenback respectively, with the former largely taking comments from Norges Bank Governor Olsen in stride as he underlined guidance for rates to remain on hold after September’s hike, barring the option to reverse the tightening move if economic developments deteriorated significantly. Meanwhile, Canadian housing starts and building permits are due and may provide the Cad with some independent direction or at least a distraction.

Mexican Central Bank Governor says adjustments have been required to the real exchange range for shocks to be absorbed by the Mexican economy, mild economic recovery is expected for the remainder of the year. (Newswires)

Notable FX Expiries, NY Cut:

- EUR/USD: 1.0915 (500M), 1.0940-50 (800M), 1.0995-1.1005 (1.3BLN), 1.1050-60 (1.5BLN), 1.1065-75 (900M)

- EUR/GBP: 0.8965 (500M)

- AUD/USD: 0.6700 (200M), 0.6740-50 (500M)

- USD/JPY: 106.50 (1.2BLN), 107.65-80 (2BLN), 108.00 (450M)

 

FIXED

Risk aversion is spreading beyond the no deal Brexit boundaries that sparked the bounce in UK debt from -¼ point Liffe lows to 135.12, so far vs yesterday’s 134.76 settlement, as latest SCMP reports appear to confirm that the Chinese delegation heading to the US is not looking for major strides to be made this week, and has changed its itinerary accordingly. Hence, Bunds have also picked up a gradual safe-haven bid to hit 174.52 (+21 ticks vs -45 ticks at one stage) and even leggy pre-US supply Treasuries have been hauled up into positive territory awaiting PPI data and Fed Chair Powell.

COMMODITIES

The crude complex is lower on Tuesday, after negative news flow on the US/China trade and Brexit front spurring risk off. WTI Nov’19 futures broke below yesterday’s USD 52.60/bbl lows and technicians will now be eyeing support just ahead of the USD 52.00/bbl handle. Meanwhile, Brent Nov’ 19 futures are probing support at USD 58.00/bbl. In terms of geopolitical developments, news flow still appears focussed on the US’ recent decision to pull troops out of Northern Syria, which opens the door for a Turkish offensive against Kurdish forces in the area (reports allege the offensive had already begun), rather than on the US/Iran/Saudi picture; given Syria’s lack of oil it remains unlikely that these developments will have much of a baring on crude prices. In supply news, the North Sea’s Buzzard Oilfield remains closed, according to its operator, and there is still no timeline for its return to normal operations. Gold prices have reclaimed the USD 1500/oz mark assisted by the aforementioned trade and Brexit jitters, after reports that China is ready to do a deal on the parts of the negotiations both sides agree upon (and is prepared to set out a timetable for the harder issues to be worked out next year) triggered a lurch lower during US hours on Monday. Copper prices saw upside overnight on decent Chinese Caixin PMI data helped to moderate concerns about an economic slowdown in the country, but has since given up the majority of its overnight gains.

CHF/EUR/JPY - All firmer against the Dollar even though the DXY nudged back over 99.000 ahead of US PPI and Fed Chair Powell, with an element of underlying safe-haven demand underpinning the Franc, Yen and Euro awaiting US-China trade talks alongside the aforementioned Brexit negotiations on the cusp of collapsing. Usd/Chf is closer to 0.9900, Eur/Usd near the top end of a 1.0965-95 band and Usd/Jpy eyeing 107.00 again from circa 107.45 earlier. Note, latest SCMP reports confirms earlier talk that Beijing is not looking for any major deal and propose to cut their stay short, with Liu He not attending in the guise of special envoy that would imply no remit or agenda to sign off on a full trade agreement.

NOK/CAD - The Norwegian Krona and Loonie are both holding relatively steady around 10.0400 vs the single currency and 1.3300 vs the Greenback respectively, with the former largely taking comments from Norges Bank Governor Olsen in stride as he underlined guidance for rates to remain on hold after September’s hike, barring the option to reverse the tightening move if economic developments deteriorated significantly. Meanwhile, Canadian housing starts and building permits are due and may provide the Cad with some independent direction or at least a distraction.

FIXED INCOME

Risk aversion is spreading beyond the no deal Brexit boundaries that sparked the bounce in UK debt from -¼ point Liffe lows to 135.12, so far vs yesterday’s 134.76 settlement, as latest SCMP reports appear to confirm that the Chinese delegation heading to the US is not looking for major strides to be made this week, and has changed its itinerary accordingly. Hence, Bunds have also picked up a gradual safe-haven bid to hit 174.52 (+21 ticks vs -45 ticks at one stage) and even leggy pre-US supply Treasuries have been hauled up into positive territory awaiting PPI data and Fed Chair Powell.

COMMODITIES                                      

The crude complex is lower on Tuesday, after negative news flow on the US/China trade and Brexit front spurring risk off. WTI Nov’19 futures broke below yesterday’s USD 52.60/bbl lows and technicians will now be eyeing support just ahead of the USD 52.00/bbl handle. Meanwhile, Brent Nov’ 19 futures are probing support at USD 58.00/bbl. In terms of geopolitical developments, news flow still appears focussed on the US’ recent decision to pull troops out of Northern Syria, which opens the door for a Turkish offensive against Kurdish forces in the area (reports allege the offensive had already begun), rather than on the US/Iran/Saudi picture; given Syria’s lack of oil it remains unlikely that these developments will have much of a baring on crude prices. In supply news, the North Sea’s Buzzard Oilfield remains closed, according to its operator, and there is still no timeline for its return to normal operations. Gold prices have reclaimed the USD 1500/oz mark assisted by the aforementioned trade and Brexit jitters, after reports that China is ready to do a deal on the parts of the negotiations both sides agree upon (and is prepared to set out a timetable for the harder issues to be worked out next year) triggered a lurch lower during US hours on Monday. Copper prices saw upside overnight on decent Chinese Caixin PMI data helped to moderate concerns about an economic slowdown in the country, but has since given up the majority of its overnight gains.

content:

  • No 10 says "talks in Brussels are close to breaking down, despite the fact the UK has moved a long way" and today's call between Merkel and Johnson is being described as a "clarifying moment"

analysis_details:
• Earlier a senior Downing Street source said that unless the EU compromises and does a Brexit deal shortly, then the UK will leave the EU without a deal. 
  • Moving forward, eyes will be on how anti-no deal MPs react to these developments. Yesterday a cross-party coalition of anti-no deal MPs failed to come an agreement to again take control of the parliamentary agenda (they would have attempted to strengthen laws that force the government to ask for an extension and perhaps brought forward the date when the government would be forced to request such an extension) after the 21 Tory rebel MPs opted to wait to allow the government more time to negotiate with the EU. Now that negotiations have effectively collapsed, these MPs join forces with the opposition and attempt to take control of the parliament.

subject: Unless the EU compromises and does a Brexit deal shortly, then the UK will leave the EU without a deal, according to a senior Downing Street source
analysis_details:
• This follows earlier reports that UK Downing Street contact believes that negotiations will probably end this week. The reports added Irish PM Varadkar does not want to talk anymore, and German Chancellor Merkel and French President Macron will not push EU’s Chief Brexit Negotiator Barnier unless Ireland says it wants to negotiate, according to The Spectator’s James Forsyth.
  • However, the a recently passed law (the Benn Act) states that if the Government is unable to get a deal with the EU before 19 October, it must on that day request an extension. The government has indicated that intends to comply with the law on this, but has indicated that it is still possible to comply with the law and leave the EU without a deal on 31 October; any extension request by the UK must be okayed by every EU27 member. Recent reports indicate that the government is mulling "sabotaging" EU operations (i.e. it could veto the 2021-2027 budget) should it be granted an extension, the threat of which the government is likely using to encourage EU member states to veto the extension request. and it has long been speculated the UK may try to persuade an EU ally to veto the request.

8th October 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equities traded higher across the board despite a lacklustre handover from Wall Street where stocks were choppy but ultimately closed in the red amid trade war jitters after the US blacklisted Chinese governmental and commercial organisations over treatment of the Muslim minority community. ASX 200 (+0.4%) was kept afloat by miners amid favourable price action in base metals, whilst Nikkei 225 (+1.0%) was bolstered on the back of a weaker Yen and after US and Japan signed a limited trade deal on agricultural and digital trade. Hang Seng (+0.8%) and Shanghai Comp (+0.8%) returned from a long weekend and played catchup to the NFP-induced upside in the prior session. The former was buoyed by heavyweights Geely Auto after dealers noted a pickup in sales during Golden Week, whilst HKEX shares rose in excess of 2% after it dropped its GBP 32bln bid for LSE, as the boards of the two companies were “unable to engage”. Meanwhile, Mainland China saw upside despite the Caixin Services metric falling short of forecasts, as an improvement in the Composite metric signalled the strongest rate of growth since April. Furthermore, South Korea’s KOSPI (+0.8%) showed a strong performance as the index was supported by tech giant Samsung Electronics, who’s shares spiked higher by 1% after its Q3 guidance topped analyst expectations, albeit it still noted that its profits will likely plunge 56% Y/Y. Finally, core fixed-income futures drifted lower and tracked the risk sentiment around the market with UST and Bund futures poised to close Asia trade near session lows.

TRADE

China is ready to do a deal on the parts of the negotiations both sides agree upon and are prepared to set out a timetable for the harder issues to be worked out next year, according to Fox citing the Chinese Commerce Ministry. The Chinese Commerce Ministry said what is not on the table and never will be is changes to their laws to protect intellectual property, adding the Chinese will deal with IP theft through administrative regulations, according to FBN's Edward Lawrence. (Twitter) US President Trump said if anything bad happened in HK, it would be bad for US/China trade talks, whilst he reiterated the US is shooting for a big deal with China and there is a good possibility of a deal. Further, the Chinese trade delegation, including Vice Premier Liu He will be in Washington on October 10/11th for trade talks. (Newswires)

US Commerce Department confirmed it is naming 28 Chinese governmental and commercial organisations - including Hikvision - to the entity list over treatment of the Muslim Uighur community, effective Monday. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC

Asian equities traded higher across the board despite a lacklustre handover from Wall Street where stocks were choppy but ultimately closed in the red amid trade war jitters after the US blacklisted Chinese governmental and commercial organisations over treatment of the Muslim minority community. ASX 200 (+0.4%) was kept afloat by miners amid favourable price action in base metals, whilst Nikkei 225 (+1.0%) was bolstered on the back of a weaker Yen and after US and Japan signed a limited trade deal on agricultural and digital trade. Hang Seng (+0.8%) and Shanghai Comp (+0.8%) returned from a long weekend and played catchup to the NFP-induced upside in the prior session. The former was buoyed by heavyweights Geely Auto after dealers noted a pickup in sales during Golden Week, whilst HKEX shares rose in excess of 2% after it dropped its GBP 32bln bid for LSE, as the boards of the two companies were “unable to engage”. Meanwhile, Mainland China saw upside despite the Caixin Services metric falling short of forecasts, as an improvement in the Composite metric signalled the strongest rate of growth since April. Furthermore, South Korea’s KOSPI (+0.8%) showed a strong performance as the index was supported by tech giant Samsung Electronics, who’s shares spiked higher by 1% after its Q3 guidance topped analyst expectations, albeit it still noted that its profits will likely plunge 56% Y/Y. Finally, core fixed-income futures drifted lower and tracked the risk sentiment around the market with UST and Bund futures poised to close Asia trade near session lows.

Hong Kong Chief Executive Lam said she has no plans to introduce other laws using the emergency regulation ordnance, it's too early to say the anti-mask law is ineffective. (Newswires) Reports, citing the Chief Executive, noted that the Chinese military could step in if the ongoing protests in the city get worse. (Sputnik) The Hong Kong leader also noted that during Golden week, the number of visitors declined 50% Y/Y. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK Downing Street contact believes that negotiations will probably end this week, and added Irish PM Varadkar does not want to talk anymore, and German Chancellor Merkel and French President Macron will not push EU’s Chief Brexit Negotiator Barnier unless Ireland says it wants to negotiate, according to The Spectator’s James Forsyth. Furthermore, UK and EU negotiators will be meeting this morning, according to Buzzfeed's Nardelli, who added that EU diplomats were also told that there haven't been significant developments on the declaration outlining the future relationship. (Twitter) A leaked document details the EU's point-by-point rejection of PM Johnson's Brexit proposals, the Guardian reports. (Guardian) UK Downing Street said the EU governments which oppose a Brexit delay will be rewarded by UK PM Johnson, and that if the EU approves a delay Johnson will do his best to sabotage the functioning of the EU, pending Brexit, ITV's Peston. (Twitter)

UK borrowing could rise to GBP 100bln in the case of a no-deal Brexit, accordion to think tank IFS. Furthermore, the body notes that the nation cannot afford the tax cuts that PM Johnson has pledged during the Conservative leadership campaign. (BBC/Times)

US Secretary of State Pompeo tweeted that he had a great discussion with UK Foreign Secretary Raab, "We discussed our intentions to negotiate an ambitious future free trade agreement, ways to counter Iran’s influence in the Middle East, and Turkey"

GEOPOLITICS 

US President Trump warns Turkey that if it does anything "off limits" he will destroy and obliterate their economy. Meanwhile, there were reports of a Turkish airstrike on Kurdish forces on the border of Syria and Iraq, according to ELINT news. Kurdish town Al-Malikiyah in northern Syria is under Turkish artillery shelling, according to ELINT News. Turkish Defence Ministry says all preparations are complete for the military operation into Syria, whilst reports stated that US does not endorse any Turkish operations in northern Syria, according to a senior administration official cited by VOA News’ Steve Herman, who added that US troops will be withdrawn from the Turkey-Syria border, not out of Syria entirely. (Twitter)

FX

 

In FX markets, DXY remained within a narrow band between 98.93-99.00, but the index traded mostly towards the bottom of the range throughout the session, ahead of today’s appearance from Fed Chair Powell and with working level US-Sino trade talks in Washington set to take place between October 10th and 11th. EUR/USD and GBP/USD initially saw some mild upside but the former hovered around 1.0975 throughout the session (ahead of 1.1bln in options expiring at strike 1.1005), whilst Cable failed to breach 1.2300 to the upside. Elsewhere, USD/JPY meandered below the 107.50 as the pair remains on standby ahead of key risk events, whilst option expiries see 1.4bln at strike 107.80 at today’s NY cut. Antipodeans outperformed as the region looks forward to working level talks between US and China later this week. NZD/USD regained 0.63+ status after the NZ Treasurer noted that the country’s final budget surplus is over NZD 4bln above original forecasts, whilst AUD/USD was little dented from disappointed data overnight and eyes 0.6750 to the upside. Finally, the Turkish Lira held onto a bulk of its losses after US President Trump warned that the US will “obliterate” Turkey’s economy if it does anything “off limits” in regards to Turkey’s long-awaited invasion of Northern Syria, although a Senior Admin Official noted that the US did not endorse Turkish operations in the region. USD/TRY remains north of 5.8000 vs. a sub-5.7000 low yesterday. 

 

Mexican Central Bank Governor says adjustments have been required to the real exchange range for shocks to be absorbed by the Mexican economy, mild economic recovery is expected for the remainder of the year. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

 

WTI and Brent futures consolidated following yesterday’s losses amid the back-and-forth China trade sentiment. The benchmarks edged higher during Asia-Pac trade, mostly on the back of risk appetite. WTI futures managed to reclaim 53/bbl to the upside ahead of its 200 WMA (53.63/bbl) whilst its Brent counterpart moved back above its respective 200 WMA (58.42/bbl) with the benchmark eyeing 59.00/bbl as the next level to the upside. Next up, traders will be paying attention to any global oil demand forecast revisions in the EIA Short Term Energy Outlook ahead of the weekly API crude inventories. Elsewhere, gold was choppy but remained below 1500/oz ahead of the upcoming risk events, whilst copper outperformed on the risk environment and as prices saw a substantial leg higher ahead of the China cash open and now resides a whisker away from 2.6/lb.

US

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z9) SETTLED 12+ TICKS LOWER AT 131-16+: Treasuries, alongside EGBs, began treading lower in the European session as participants became cautiously optimistic in anticipation of US-China trade talks (reflective in major equity bourses, too), although some ominous updates ahead of the meetings failed to reverse the sell-off (it reversed the gains in equities), desks also noted dealer book squaring ahead of a heavy supply schedule at auctions later in the week. There was a pare back of last week’s bull steepening in anticipation of further Fed easing post the poor ISM data, with the overhang of Friday’s relatively decent payrolls report cooling some of the October cut pricing. Looking ahead, Fed Chair Powell is scheduled to provide remarks on monetary policy on Tuesday, too, where the market will be looking for some confirmation on whether the Fed is onboard with an October rate cut. At Treasury settlement yields were higher, seeing the curve bear flatten – 2s10s narrowed by 3.5bps, taking the spread back beneath 10bps.

subject: ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Stocks rise in anticipation of trade talks in Washington, HK and Mainland returned from a long weekend
content:
Asian equities trade higher across the board despite a lacklustre handover from Wall Street where stocks were choppy but ultimately closed in the red amid trade war jitters after the US blacklisted Chinese governmental and commercial organisations over treatment of the Muslim minority community. ASX 200 (+0.5%) is supported by miners amid favourable price action in base metals, whilst Nikkei 225 (+1.0%) outperforms on the back of a weaker Yen and after US and Japan signed a limited trade deal on agricultural and digital trade. Hang Seng (+1.2%) and Shanghai Comp (+0.5%) returned from a long weekend and played catchup to the NFP-induced upside in the prior session. The former is buoyed by heavyweights Geely Auto after dealers noted a pickup in sales during Golden Week, whilst HKEX shares rose in excess of 2% after it dropped its GBP 32bln bid for LSE, as the boards of the two companies were “unable to engage”. Meanwhile, Mainland China saw upside after an improvement in the Caixin Composite PMI metric which signalled the strongest rate of growth since April. Further, South Korea’s KOSPI (+0.9%) is performing strongly with the index buoyed by Samsung Electronics, who’s shares spiked higher by 1% after its Q3 guidance topped analyst expectations, albeit it still noted that its profits likely fell 56% Y/Y.

 

In FX, DXY remains within a narrow band between 98.94-99.00, but the index traded mostly towards the bottom of the range throughout the session, ahead of today’s appearance from Fed Chair Powell and working level US-Sino trade talks in Washington, with dialogue set to take place between October 10th and 11th. EUR/USD and GBP/USD see some mild upside as the former moved back above 1.0975 ahead of 1.1bln in options expiring at strike 1.1005, whilst Cable tests 1.2300 to the upside. Elsewhere, USD/JPY meandered below the 107.50 as the pair remains on standby ahead of key risk events, whilst option expiries see 1.4bln at strike 107.80. Antipodeans outperformed as the region looks forward to working level talks between US and China later this week. NZD/USD regained 0.63+ status after the NZ Treasurer noted that the country’s final budget surplus is over NZD 4bln above original forecasts, whilst AUD/USD eyes 0.6750 to the upside. Finally, the Turkish Lira held onto a bulk of its losses after US President Trump warned that the US will “obliterate” Turkey’s economy if it does anything “off limits” in regards to Turkey’s long-awaited invasion of Northern Syria, although a Senior Admin Official noted that the US did not endorse Turkish operations in the region. USD/TRY remains north of 5.8000 after testing 5.8450 to the upside vs. a sub-5.7000 low yesterday.

subject: PRE-MARKET CHINESE  STOCK NEWS:US Commerce Department confirms it is naming 28 Chinese governmental and commercial organisations - including Hikvision - to the entity list over treatment of the Muslim Uighur community, effective Monday. (Newswires)
content:
CHINA

Hong Kong Exchange (388 HK) – Co. said it will not proceed with its offer for LSE (LSE LN) (Newswires)

Hikvision (002415 CH) - US Commerce Department confirms it is naming 28 Chinese governmental and commercial organisations - including Hikvision - to the entity list over treatment of the Muslim Uighur community, effective Monday. (Newswires)

Coolpad (2369 HK) – Co. will allot and issue 800mln subscription shares at HKD 0.215/shr. (Newswires)

China construction bank (939 HK) – Co. has suspended services at some HK branches for maintenance. (Newswires)

Guangdong No2 Hydropower (002060 CH) – Consortium has been awarded a water plant project worth CNY 480mln. (Newswires)

BYD (1211 HK) – co. set up a CNY 1.1bln fund with a unit of China Vanke. (Newswires)

Chongqing Changan Auto (000625 CH) – Co’s Hefei unit received subsidies worth CNY 420mln. (Newswires)

Shenzhen Green (002340 CH) – Co. entered into an agreement to acquire cobalt resources from Glencore, terms undisclosed. (Newswires)

Zoomlion Heavy Industries (0001547 CH) – Regulator has approved plans to issue CNY 2.0bln in bonds. (Newswires)

Chongqing Jianfeng (000950 CH) – Shareholders are to sell up to 3% stake in the Co. within 3 months. (Newswires)

Shenzhen Salubris Pharma (002294 CH) – Co. announced a CNY 250-300mln share buyback programme (Newswires)

Geely Auto (0175 HK) – Dealers noted a pickup in sales and sentiment during Golden Week. (Newswires)

 

Other News

- China is ready to do a deal on the parts of the negotiations both sides agree upon and are prepared to set out a timetable for the harder issues to be worked out next year, according to Fox citing the Chinese Commerce Ministry. The Chinese Commerce Ministry said what is not in the table and never will be is changes to their laws to protect intellectual property, adding the Chinese will deal with IP theft through administrative regulations, according to FBN's Edward Lawrence. (Twitter) US President Trump says if anything bad happened in Hong Kong, it would be bad for US/China trade talks. (Newswires)

- China is still buying US soybeans as trade talks resume, recently making its largest purchase of the agricultural product in more than a year. (WSJ)

- NEC Director Kudlow said the delisting of Chinese Co's is not on the table. He does think that the impeachment controversy is having an effect on trade negotiations with China; says further progress could be made later this week and he is open to see what China brings to the table (Newswires)

 

Data recap

- China Golden Week domestic tourism CNY 649.7bln +7.5% Y/Y, Box office sales CNY 4.2bln, +120.9% Y/Y. (Newswires)
